description:
Mus spretus, commonly known as the Spanish mouse, is a small rodent species belonging to the genus Mus, which includes various species of mice. This species is native to the Iberian Peninsula, primarily found in Spain and Portugal.

Mus spretus is a relatively small mouse, with an average body length of around 8-10 cm and a weight of approximately 12-20 grams. The species has a grayish-brown fur coat on its dorsal (upper) side and a lighter, almost white, ventral (lower) side. The ears and tail are also covered with short fur.

Mus spretus is a nocturnal and terrestrial species, typically inhabiting a variety of habitats, including grasslands, scrublands, and agricultural areas. It is known to be an opportunistic feeder, with a diet that includes seeds, grains, fruits, and small invertebrates.

The reproductive biology of Mus spretus is characterized by a relatively short gestation period of around 19-21 days, with females typically giving birth to litters of 4-8 young. The species is known to have a relatively high reproductive rate, with the potential to produce multiple litters per year.

Mus spretus is considered a pest species in some agricultural regions due to its potential to cause damage to crops and stored grains. However, it also plays an important role in the ecosystem as a prey species for various predators, such as birds of prey, snakes, and small carnivores.
